Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether s. 44 of the IRPA violates separation of powers or procedural fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 44
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed their visas, were denied visitor status extension, and requested adjournment to await humanitarian and compassionate application processing
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the constitutionality of s. 44 and refusal of adjournment
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Section 44 does not violate separation of powers; no breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign nationals who overstayed their authorized stay
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Failed to leave Canada by the authorized date and sought delay in removal proceedings
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Pending humanitarian and compassionate grounds application
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Principle of separation of powers; duty of procedural fairness
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Balance between administrative efficiency and fair process in immigration enforcement
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Refusal of adjournment during admissibility hearing
Crimes.Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa status records, application for visitor extension, humanitarian and compassionate application submission
Crimes.Application_Basis: Inadmissibility due to overstaying authorized period
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Timeliness and merits of humanitarian application pending during removal process
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Adjournment of admissibility hearing and judicial review of s. 44
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Immigration officers may issue removal orders without judicial involvement under s. 44
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No finding of deficiency; applicants failed to demonstrate urgency or likelihood of success in humanitarian claim
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order upheld; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Potential hardship from removal balanced against immigration compliance
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicants remained in Canada beyond their authorized stay and sought to delay removal based on a pending humanitarian application
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Administrative record reviewed; no new evidence introduced to justify adjournment
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44 of the IRPA (basis for removal order)
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: No significant disputes over evidence authenticity or relevance
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – failed to depart by authorized date
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Constitutionality of administrative removal process under federal law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Humanitarian application was pending but not yet processed; insufficient to warrant delay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 44 is constitutionally valid; delegate acted fairly in refusing adjournment
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Separation of powers; procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
